SystemOutput: HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Mr. Andrew is a 59-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type two diabetes, and hypertension who presents today with an upper respiratory infection. He reports feeling tired and short of breath while doing yard work and carrying heavy bags of soil. He believes he caught a cold that has worsened. He has received both COVID-19 vaccines and denies any history of seasonal allergies. He experiences shortness of breath while lifting or carrying heavy objects and has pain in his elbows and knees.  Mr. Andrew has been managing his depression without medication and has been attending barre classes to help him relax. He has been monitoring his blood sugar levels during the week and maintains a good diet, with occasional exceptions for house parties. He has been taking his blood pressure medication and monitoring his blood pressure regularly during the week.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Constitutional: No fever. Positive fatigue. • Respiratory: Positive shortness of breath. Positive cough. • Musculoskeletal: Positive joint pain in elbows and knees.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Vital Signs: Normal. • Respiratory: Scattered ronchi bilaterally, clears with cough. • Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. • Musculoskeletal: Edema in lower extremities. Pain to palpation of elbows bilaterally.  RESULTS  Chest X-ray: Unremarkable, no airspace disease or pneumonia.  Diabetic labs: Hemoglobin A1c elevated at 8.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Upper Respiratory Infection: Likely viral syndrome. Will send a COVID test to rule out COVID-19. Prescribe Robitussin for cough and recommend ibuprofen or Tylenol for fever.  2. Depression: Patient is managing well without medication. Offered medical treatment or psychotherapy referral if needed in the future.  3. Type 2 Diabetes: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c in four months.  4. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel. Refill lisinopril prescription.  Follow-up appointment in four months. Patient to notify the doctor if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Annual exam.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  The patient is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history significant for rheumatoid arthritis, atrial fibrillation, and reflux who presents today for her annual exam. The patient reports that she has been walking, exercising, and doing yoga, which has helped with her arthritis. She denies any joint pain recently. She is taking methotrexate once a week. The patient reports that she has been having palpitations, with the last episode occurring a week ago. She has tried meditation and running with her dog to relieve stress but has not found it helpful. The patient reports that her reflux has improved since cutting out soda and taking protonix. She has not had a flare-up in over five months.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Cardiovascular: Endorses palpitations. • Gastrointestinal: Denies reflux flare-ups. • Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain or stiffness. • Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath. • ENT: Endorses nasal congestion due to allergies.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Constitutional: Appears well. • Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, regular rate and rhythm. • Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. • Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the right elbow, with edema and erythema. No lower extremity edema.  RESULTS  Event monitor: Shows in and out of atrial fibrillation with conversion pauses.  Autoimmune panel: Stable, well-controlled rheumatoid arthritis on methotrexate.  ASSESSMENT  1. Rheumatoid arthritis: Stable on methotrexate 2.5 mg once weekly. Continue current treatment and refill prescription. 2. Atrial fibrillation: In and out of atrial fibrillation with conversion pauses. Refer to cardiology for cardiac ablation to maintain normal sinus rhythm. 3. Reflux: Improved with protonix 40 mg daily and dietary modifications. Continue current treatment and monitor for any issues.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Emergency room follow-up.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Albert is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant, who is here today for emergency room follow-up. He was in the emergency room due to elevated blood sugar levels. He admits to not monitoring his blood sugar closely and eating poorly due to his mother's recent hospitalization. Since then, he has been following his diet more closely.  In terms of his kidney transplant, he has been diligent about taking his immunosuppression medications and his kidney function is stable. Regarding his depression, he has been managing it with meditation and would like to continue that approach.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Constitutional: No fevers, chills. • Cardiovascular: No chest pain or dyspnea. • Respiratory: No shortness of breath. • Neurological: No dizziness or lightheadedness. • Psychiatric: Endorses depression.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur. • Musculoskeletal: 1+ edema in bilateral lower extremities.  RESULTS  Non-fasting glucose is elevated at 162.  Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  Albert is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, type 2 diabetes, and kidney transplant. He presents today for emergency room follow-up.  Hyperglycemia. • Medical Reasoning: His blood sugar levels have been elevated, and his hemoglobin A1c is 8. • Medical Treatment: Increase Lantus to 20 units at night. Continue monitoring blood sugar levels. Order hemoglobin A1c in a couple of months.  Depression. • Medical Reasoning: He has been managing his depression with meditation and would like to continue that approach. • Medical Treatment: Continue current strategies with meditation. Hold off on medication or therapy at this time.  Kidney transplant. • Medical Reasoning: His kidney function is stable, and he is taking his immunosuppression medications as prescribed. • Medical Treatment: Continue follow-up with Dr. Reyes for management of immunosuppression medications.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Annual exam.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  The patient is a 54-year-old male with a past medical history significant for osteoporosis and multiple sclerosis. He presents for an annual exam. The patient reports traveling all over the country and experiencing a stressful summer. He has been struggling with insomnia and has tried various strategies, including melatonin, meditation, and stretching, but nothing seems to help.  The patient has been taking Fosamax for osteoporosis and has not experienced any joint issues or broken bones recently. He saw a neurologist six months ago for his multiple sclerosis and is taking medication for it without any issues. He reports some lingering weakness in his right leg due to knee surgery but has not experienced any additional weakness.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Sleep: Endorses insomnia. • Musculoskeletal: No joint issues or broken bones. • Neurological: Multiple sclerosis, weakness in right leg.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Vital signs: Within normal limits. • Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally. • Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal. • Musculoskeletal: Right lower extremity strength 4/5, left lower extremity strength 3/5. Reflexes are good. Arthritic changes in the right knee.  RESULTS  Right knee x-ray: Shows changes from arthritis.  ASSESSMENT  1. Osteoporosis • Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently on Fosamax for osteoporosis management. • Medical Treatment: Continue Fosamax. Refill ordered for 1 tab per week, 11 refills.  2. Multiple sclerosis • Medical Reasoning: The patient is under the care of a neurologist and is taking medication for multiple sclerosis. • Medical Treatment: Continue to see the neurologist and continue on medications. Notify the primary care physician if any issues arise.  3. Insomnia • Medical Reasoning: The patient has tried various strategies to address insomnia without success. • Medical Treatment: No specific treatment plan discussed during this visit.

CC:  Distal radius pain.  HPI:  Mrs. Martinez is a 43-year-old female who presents today with pain in her distal radius. She reports that the pain began while playing tennis and hitting the net pole during a backhand swing. She experienced some swelling but no numbness in her hand. She has a past medical history of allergies and takes Flonase. She has a past surgical history of a trauma from falling on a rake.  EXAM:  Examination of the arm shows tenderness over the distal radius. Pain is present when the thumb is stressed and flexed. No fractures are seen on the x-ray.  IMPRESSION:  Distal radius strain and contusion.  PLAN:  At this point, I recommend conservative treatment with ice and anti-inflammatory medication. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg three times a day with food. If the pain does not improve in the next week, the patient should follow up for reevaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Shortness of breath.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history of type I diabetes, congestive heart failure, depression, and reflux.  SOCIAL HISTORY  Patient reports attending house parties and consuming salty foods.  MEDICATIONS  Patient is on insulin pump for diabetes and omeprazole for reflux.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Constitutional: Reports lethargy and swelling in legs. Cardiovascular: Reports shortness of breath when walking up stairs. Respiratory: Denies cough, fever, or chills. Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain. Psychiatric: Reports depression but denies suicidal ideation.  VITALS  Pulse oximetry: Normal  PHYSICAL EXAM  Neck: No jugular venous distension or carotid bruits. Cardiovascular: 3 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur. Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally at the bases. Lower extremities: 1+ pitting edema.  LABS AND IMAGING  Chest X-ray: No evidence of airspace disease. Labs: No elevated white blood cell count.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Shortness of breath. - Medical Reasoning: Acute heart failure exacerbation. - Medical Treatment: Lasix 40 mg daily, daily weight monitoring, and follow-up if weight increases or shortness of breath worsens.  2. Type I diabetes. - Medical Reasoning: Monitoring blood sugar control. - Medical Treatment: Order hemoglobin A1c in a month, follow up with endocrinologist, and ensure a recent eye exam.  3. Depression. - Medical Reasoning: Patient prefers non-pharmacological treatment. - Medical Treatment: Referral to psychiatry for talk therapy.  4. Reflux. - Medical Reasoning: Patient is currently on omeprazole. - Medical Treatment: Continue omeprazole 20 mg daily.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.  INSTRUCTIONS  The patient is advised to call the doctor if there are any issues with breathing or if weight increases.

CC:  Right index finger pain.  HPI:  Ms. James is a 42-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right index finger pain. She states she was skiing on a double black diamond slope last Saturday and lost control, jamming her index finger during the fall. She has tried taking Ibuprofen, but it did not seem to help. She rates her pain as a 7 out of 10.  CURRENT MEDICATIONS:  MiraLax  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:  Chronic constipation.  PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:  Appendectomy at age 7.  EXAM:  Examination of the right index finger shows tenderness and pain when pressed, pulled, and squeezed over the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP joint).  RESULTS:  X-rays of the right hand show no obvious signs of fracture or bony abnormalities.  IMPRESSION:  Sprain of the distal interphalangeal joint (DIP joint) of the right index finger.  PLAN:  At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended a splint for her right index finger. She will take Mobic 15 mg once a day for 14 days. She will follow up with me in two weeks to ensure proper healing and discuss any necessary hand therapy. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Back pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Cheryl is a 34-year-old female with a past medical history significant for hypertension, who presents today with back pain. She reports walking 30 minutes to an hour daily and experiencing a sudden back spasm six days ago. She has been taking ibuprofen and applying heat to the area, but the pain persists. Cheryl has also been lifting weights three times a week, including deadlifts.  Regarding her hypertension, Cheryl has been monitoring her blood pressure at home and reports that it has been well controlled. She is taking lisinopril as prescribed.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable. • Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation on the right lateral aspect of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension. Negative straight leg raise.  VITALS REVIEWED  • Blood Pressure: Well controlled in the office.  RESULTS  Lumbar spine x-ray: Good bony alignment, no obvious fracture.  Labs: No elevated white blood cell count, no signs of infection.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Lumbar strain.    • Medical Reasoning: Likely due to lifting or exercising.    • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day. Ice the area and apply heat as needed.    • Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises.  2. Hypertension.    • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure is well controlled.    • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 10 mg daily. Monitor blood pressure readings and report any increases.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:  Left shoulder pain.  HPI:  Mrs. Anderson is a 44-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of left shoulder pain that has been present for a week. She states the pain started after a gymnastics class where she may have injured herself during a certain move. She has tried taking Tylenol for two to three days, but it did not help. She has a past surgical history of a left arm surgery.  EXAM:  Examination of the left shoulder shows pain with movement in both forward and backward directions.  RESULTS:  X-rays of the left shoulder do not show any broken bones or fractures.  IMPRESSION:  Left shoulder joint pain, likely due to injury during gymnastics.  PLAN:  At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended she continue using pain relievers, such as 600 mg of ibuprofen three times a day for a week. She can also use ice or heat pads to help relieve pain. She should rest her left arm and avoid carrying heavy weights for the next three to four weeks. She can follow up in three weeks if the pain persists, at which point we may consider further imaging.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Annual exam.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Elizabeth is a 66-year-old female with a past medical history significant for depression and hypertension. She presents for her annual exam. She has been managing her depression with weekly therapy sessions and has a good support system at home. She has been monitoring her blood pressure with a cuff and taking lisinopril as prescribed.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion. • Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. • Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath. • Psychiatric: Endorses depression.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect. • Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. • Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable. • Extremities: Trace lower extremity edema bilaterally.  VITALS REVIEWED  • Blood Pressure: Within normal limits. • Heart Rate: Within normal limits.  RESULTS  Electrocardiogram: Normal.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Depression.    • Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing her depression well with therapy and support from her family.    • Medical Treatment: Continue current management strategies.    • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to contact me if she feels the need for medication.  2. Hypertension.    • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well controlled with lisinopril.    • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.    • Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to continue monitoring her blood pressure and contact me if it starts to rise.  3. Annual exam maintenance.    • Medical Reasoning: The patient is due for a mammogram.    • Medical Treatment: Schedule a mammogram.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Left shoulder and elbow pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  The patient fell on his left side while going up icy stairs five months ago. He has been experiencing constant pain in his left shoulder and elbow since the fall. The pain worsens when lifting weights, and he has stopped going to the gym due to the pain. He continues to walk for 30 minutes daily with his wife.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Left shoulder and elbow: Tender, no warmth, erythema, or deformity. Positive Hawkins-Kennedy and Neer's test. Normal proximal and distal upper extremity strength. Intact median radial ulnar sensation and abduction to 90 degrees. Normal empty can test.  ASSESSMENT  Impingement syndrome of the left shoulder.  PLAN  1. Physical therapy: The patient will start with two sessions per week and any additional exercises provided by the therapist. 2. Cortisone injection: If physical therapy does not improve the pain, a cortisone injection may be considered. 3. Continue icing and resting the shoulder. 4. Follow up if symptoms worsen or do not improve with therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Runny nose, stuffy nose, cough, and low-grade fever.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Randy Gutierrez is a 1-year-old male who presents with symptoms of a runny nose, stuffy nose, cough, and low-grade fever starting last night. His mother reports that his older sister has been sick recently, and they had a playdate with a nephew who had a sinus infection. Randy's appetite has been variable, and he has been irritable. His mother has been using saline mist in his nose, Tylenol, baby Vick's on his feet, and a humidifier to help alleviate his symptoms.  PAST HISTORY  Cradle cap.  SOCIAL HISTORY  Lives with his mother and older sister.  VITALS  Rectal temperature: 100.3°F  PHYSICAL EXAM  Constitutional: Alert and irritable. Nasal: Mucous is clear. Ears: No signs of infection. Lungs: Clear to auscultation.  ASSESSMENT  Viral upper respiratory infection.  PLAN  1. Continue with saline mist, Tylenol, baby Vick's, and humidifier as needed. 2. Monitor for the development of a barky cough. If it develops, give half a teaspoon of his sister's medicine for five days. 3. For cradle cap, use a dandruff shampoo (Head & Shoulders, Selsun Blue, or Nizoral AD) twice a week, avoiding the eyes. Continue using a soft brush and baby oil to remove scales. 4. Follow up in one week to assess progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Acne on the face.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Kayla Ward is a 13-year-old female who presents with her mother for acne located on the face, which started about two years ago and is present most every day. She has been using Persa-Gel and washing regularly, which is somewhat helpful. There are no associated symptoms including itching, bleeding, or pain. No additional past medical history. She lives with her parents and sister. They have a dog, bird, and bunnies. She is in 7th grade. She plays basketball, volleyball, and tap. She wears sunscreen in the summer, SPF 30. No additional family history.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Skin: Multiple benign nevi on the trunk and extremities. Scattered skin-colored papules. Open and closed comedones. Erythematous papules on the face, primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin. The chest and back are relatively spared. The remainder of the examination is normal.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  Mild to moderate acne, mostly comodonal with a small inflammatory component. Recommended topical therapy with a mild cleanser, noncomedogenic moisturizer with sunscreen SPF 30 or higher in the morning, and adapalene 0.1% cream in the evening, followed by Clean and Clear Persa-Gel and a noncomedogenic moisturizer. The patient is advised to wear sunscreen when outside due to the sensitivity caused by the topical retinoid. A follow-up appointment is scheduled for six months to assess progress.

Julia Jones, a 25-year-old female, presented for a breast reduction consultation with Dr. Gonzalez. She has been considering the procedure for about six or seven years due to back pain, neck pain, and discomfort during physical activities. Julia has a history of breast cancer in her family and is currently studying psychology. She has lost 10 pounds recently and plans to lose 20 more.  Dr. Gonzalez discussed the breast reduction procedure, including the incisions, removal of fat and glandular tissue, and potential changes in nipple sensation. She also mentioned that 30% of patients may not be able to breastfeed after the surgery. Julia is aware that her breasts may change with pregnancy and weight fluctuations.  Julia's insurance will be changing soon, so Dr. Gonzalez suggested waiting until July to submit the approval request. In the meantime, they will take photos and document her symptoms for the insurance company. Once approved, they will schedule a surgery date and meet again to discuss further details and instructions.  Julia is an ideal candidate for bilateral reduction mammoplasty, and Dr. Gonzalez believes she will benefit from the procedure.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Hematuria  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient reports passing two small stones last week and experiencing episodes of bright red urine for the past six weeks.  MEDICATIONS  Alavert 10 mg daily  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Genitourinary: Reports dysuria and frequent urination last week. Denies current flank pain or tenderness in the lower back.  RESULTS  Renal ultrasound: Right kidney measures 10 cm in length and 5 cm in width, with no stones, masses, or hydronephrosis. Left kidney measures 10.8 cm in length and 5 cm in width, with a 6 mm non-obstructing left renal stone. Urine dipstick shows a trace amount of blood.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Hematuria: Likely due to kidney stones. Blood in urine has nearly subsided. No surgical intervention recommended at this time. 2. Chronic urolithiasis: Patient has one remaining stone in the left kidney. Advised to increase water intake, avoid sugary drinks, and modify diet to reduce sodium, oxalate, and animal protein intake.  INSTRUCTIONS  Patient is provided with a handout on dietary recommendations to prevent kidney stones. Follow-up appointment scheduled for next year, unless issues arise sooner. If severe pain or bright red blood in urine occurs, the patient should go to the emergency room.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Melissa Sanchez is a 58-year-old female who presents for a follow-up visit after her mitral valve repair surgery on 8/3/2020. She has a history of mitral regurgitation, atrial fibrillation, diabetes, asthma, and recurrent chest discomfort with negative cardiac workup for coronary artery disease. At her previous follow-up on 9/17, she was doing well from a cardiac standpoint, and her medications were continued. Her ECG taken on 12/26/2020 reveals atrial fibrillation with a controlled ventricular response and T-wave inversion anteriorly.  Ms. Sanchez reports feeling better overall since her surgery, but she still experiences occasional chest pain and shallow breathing. These episodes last a few minutes and occur a couple of times a month. She has learned to slow down and rest when these symptoms occur.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  Head and Neck • No JVD detected.  Respiratory • Reduced breath sounds, but auscultation and percussion are clear.  Cardiovascular • Rhythm is irregularly irregular (atrial fibrillation). • S1 slightly accentuated, no S3.  Gastrointestinal • Abdomen is non-tender.  Extremities • Trace peripheral edema.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  Ms. Sanchez is recovering well from her mitral valve repair surgery. Her atrial fibrillation is well controlled with her current medications, which include Coumadin 4 mg, Lasix 4 mg, and Atenolol 50 mg daily. She is advised to continue her current medications and maintain an active lifestyle within her body's limits. A follow-up visit is recommended in six to nine months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Psoriatic arthritis management.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Judy Gomez is a 60-year-old female with a history of psoriatic arthritis. She reports that she has been doing well on her current treatment plan, which includes decreasing her prednisone dose. She is now on one prednisone tablet and has occasionally taken an extra one due to increased pain in her feet. She also reports that methotrexate has been helpful in managing her joint pain.  The patient did not take methotrexate during the week of her first COVID-19 vaccine dose due to concerns about its potential interference with the vaccine's efficacy. However, she experienced significant pain during that week and resumed taking methotrexate for her second vaccine dose.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  • Musculoskeletal: Joint pain in feet, improved with methotrexate. • Integumentary: Bruising, likely due to prednisone use.  PHYSICAL EXAMINATION  • Musculoskeletal: Good range of motion in toes and knees. Ridges in nails due to psoriasis.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  Judy Gomez is a 60-year-old female with a history of psoriatic arthritis. She is currently on a treatment plan that includes decreasing her prednisone dose and continuing methotrexate.  Psoriatic arthritis. • Medical Reasoning: The patient's joint pain has improved with methotrexate, and she is working on discontinuing prednisone. • Medical Treatment: Discontinue prednisone and continue methotrexate. • Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should be aware that bruising may be due to prednisone use and may improve after discontinuation.  The patient should schedule an appointment for blood work to monitor her response to methotrexate. A follow-up appointment should be scheduled in three months to assess her progress.

Diana Scott is a 100-year-old female who presents with a new worrisome heart murmur. She denies chest pain but has severe leg pain and occasional shortness of breath when walking too fast or too long. She has been experiencing swelling in her ankles for about six months. She has a family history of heart problems and has never smoked. She is currently taking amlodipine, lisinopril, simvastatin, and levothyroxine.  Physical examination revealed a 4/6 systolic murmur at the right upper sternal border with mild radiation to the carotids. EKG showed sinus rhythm with frequent PVCs and an anterior septum infarct pattern.  The plan is to schedule an echocardiogram to assess overall cardiac structure and function, as well as the severity of her aortic stenosis. Depending on the results, further evaluation for ischemic heart disease or a heart monitor to assess the burden of PVCs may be considered. No changes to her current medications are recommended at this time, but the possibility of stopping her statin may be discussed with her primary care physician. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in three to four weeks to discuss the results of the echocardiogram and next steps.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Charles is a 46-year-old male who presents to the clinic today with complaints of shortness of breath, watery eyes, and eye boogers. He has noticed these symptoms in various situations, including inside and outside his house and around his cat. He has used an albuterol inhaler when symptoms arise, which has provided some relief. He has no history of allergies and denies experiencing any rash, nausea, vomiting, lip or throat swelling.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Vitals: Pulse and pulse ox are normal. General: No distress, no rash, no angioedema, no audible stridor. Respiratory: Faint expiratory wheezing bilaterally in all lung fields.  IMAGING  Chest X-ray and pulmonary function test were both normal.  ASSESSMENT  Newly diagnosed allergic asthma.  PLAN  1. Continue albuterol inhaler as needed for symptoms. 2. Prescribe Singulair 10 mg daily to help decrease asthma occurrences. 3. Schedule allergy skin testing to identify triggers. 4. Follow up in one week to discuss skin testing results and potential further testing or immunotherapy if needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Low back pain and tingling in the right leg.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  The patient was raking leaves in the yard when the pain started. The pain has been present for about 6 hours. The patient has a history of a similar episode about three years ago, which resolved after a day.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports low back pain and tingling in the right leg. Denies any other joint pain or swelling.  VITALS  Not provided in the dialogue.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Musculoskeletal - Low back: Pain on palpation around L5. Pain on flexion and extension. - Lower extremities: Dorsiflexion is normal. Pulses are equal in all extremities.  RESULTS  X-ray of the low back is normal.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Low back sprain. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with a low back sprain. - Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam for pain relief and inflammation. Recommend rest and physical therapy to improve strength and flexibility. - Follow-up: If the pain does not improve in two weeks, consider an MRI to further evaluate the cause of the pain.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Non-healing foot ulcer.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Gregory is a patient with a history of diabetes who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer for about two months. He believes he may have gotten it from walking barefoot on the beach. The ulcer has recently become red and is draining. He has been prescribed medication but has not picked it up from the pharmacy yet. He experiences occasional throbbing but no specific pain.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient has a history of diabetes.  MEDICATIONS  Patient takes medication for diabetes but does not check his sugar regularly.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Skin: Patient reports a non-healing foot ulcer that is red and draining.  VITALS  No fever.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Foot exam: 1x2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, proximal to the fifth MTP joint. Redness, drainage, and edema present. No necrosis, odor, or bony exposure.  ASSESSMENT  1. Diabetic foot ulcer 2. Infection  PLAN  1. Order an ABI (ankle-brachial index) to determine blood supply in the foot. 2. Perform a debridement to remove dead tissue. 3. Prescribe Clindamycin 400mg twice a day for seven days to treat the infection. 4. Provide a surgical shoe for the patient to wear for the next month to reduce pressure on the foot. 5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in two weeks for possible further debridement and evaluation of the wound healing progress.  In case of any issues or emergencies, the patient is advised to call the office or visit urgent care/ER as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Left ankle pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Stephanie Morales is a 36-year-old female with a history of diabetes and high blood pressure who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of left ankle pain. The onset of her pain began two days ago when she slipped on ice and her left ankle twisted underneath her. She reports that her ankle is swollen and painful, making it difficult to walk. The patient has been using ibuprofen, ice, and elevation to manage her pain and swelling, which has provided some relief.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  Diabetes, high blood pressure.  MEDICATIONS  Metformin, Norvasc.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Positive left ankle pain and swelling. Skin: No bleeding. Neurological: Denies any numbness or tingling.  VITALS  BP: 120/70  PHYSICAL EXAM  CV: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged from previous exams. MSK: Examination of the left ankle reveals tenderness over the lateral malleolus and the fifth metatarsal. Swelling and redness are present. Pain with valgus stressing of the ankle. Sensation and pulses are normal.  ASSESSMENT  Left ankle sprain, possible fracture.  PLAN  1. Order an x-ray of the left ankle to rule out a fracture. 2. Place the patient in an air splint and provide crutches for non-weight-bearing until x-ray results are available. 3. Prescribe Naprosyn 500 mg twice a day for pain control. 4. Advise the patient to continue icing and elevating the ankle. 5. If the x-ray shows a fracture, refer the patient to orthopedics. If no fracture is present, allow the patient to begin partial weight-bearing and monitor progress.  Diabetes management: 1. Continue with Metformin and maintain a healthy diet. 2. Order a Hemoglobin A1c test. 3. Encourage the patient to keep her upcoming ophthalmologist appointment.  High blood pressure management: 1. Refill Norvasc prescription. 2. Continue monitoring blood pressure and contact the office if any changes occur.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Diabetic foot ulcer.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Wayne is a 31-year-old male with a history of diabetes who presents with a non-healing wound on his right foot for the past 2-3 weeks. The wound initially started as a blister caused by tight shoes, but has since worsened. The patient has neuropathy and cannot feel the wound. He has completed a course of antibiotics prescribed by his primary care physician, but the wound has not improved. He denies any fever, chills, or drainage from the wound.  VITALS  Temperature: 98.1 Heart rate: 72 Respirations: 16 Blood pressure: 110/65  PHYSICAL EXAM  Foot exam: 1x2 inch circular wound on the dorsal aspect of the lateral right foot, just proximal to the right fifth MTP joint. Yellow slough present with minimal granulation tissue. No surrounding erythema, cellulitis, fluid collection, necrosis, or odor. No bony exposure. Vascular exam: palpable bilateral femoral and popliteal pulses, no palpable DP or PT pulses, but Doppler signals are present.  RESULTS  Right foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.  ASSESSMENT  1. Diabetic foot ulcer 2. Diabetes  PLAN  1. Order an ankle-brachial index (ABI) to determine blood supply to the foot. 2. Perform debridement in the office to remove dead tissue. 3. Prescribe collagenase ointment to be applied to the wound once daily and cover with a dry sterile dressing. 4. Wear a surgical shoe to take pressure off the area. 5. No further antibiotics needed at this time. 6. Follow up in two weeks; may need referral to a vascular specialist if ABI indicates poor blood supply for wound healing. 7. Diabetic consult to discuss diet modifications to improve diabetes control.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Right knee pain after trampoline park incident.  SOCIAL HISTORY  The patient does not have a consistent exercise regimen and went to the trampoline park for fun.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain on the lateral aspect. Denies any other joint pain.  VITALS  Blood pressure: 180/80 mmHg  PHYSICAL EXAM  Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs. Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally. Musculoskeletal: Right knee with ecchymosis and edema on the lateral aspect. No effusion. Limited range of motion due to pain. Gait with a limp.  RESULTS  X-ray of the right knee: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Right knee pain - Lateral ligament strain. - Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily for pain and swelling. - Referral: Physical therapy for strengthening and injury prevention. - Follow-up: Consider further imaging if pain persists.  2. Hypertension - Continue lisinopril 20 mg. - Order echocardiogram. - Consider medication modification if blood pressure remains uncontrolled.  3. Diabetes - Order A1c and lipid panel for long-term blood sugar management and potential medication adjustments.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Lower back pain and left leg pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Matthew is a 31-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of lower back pain and left leg pain. The patient reports that his back pain has been bothering him for a long time, but it has worsened significantly in the past month. He describes the pain as an electrical toothache that radiates from his lower back, through his hip, and down his left leg. The pain is currently a 6 out of 10 but can reach up to a 13 out of 10 when it is at its worst. The patient finds relief when lying down, but standing, walking, coughing, and sneezing exacerbate the pain. He has a history of a fall from a roof 30 years ago, which may have caused a fracture.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Positive for lower back pain and left leg pain. Neurological: Denies any numbness or tingling.  VITALS  BP: 120/80 SPO2: 98%.  PHYSICAL EXAM  CV: Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Strong dorsalis pedis pulse. NEURO: Normal sensation. Sensation is intact to light touch distally. MSK: Examination of the lower back reveals no bony abnormalities, redness, or bruising. Positive for pain to palpation at the L4 vertebrae. Positive for pain with flexion and extension of the back. Strength is 4 out of 5 in the left leg and 5 out of 5 in the right leg. Reflexes are brisk, and motor and sensory are intact in both lower extremities.  RESULTS  MRI of the lumbar spine reveals a disk herniation at the level of L4-L5 vertebrae with nerve root impingement.  ASSESSMENT  Acute disk herniation at L4-L5 with nerve root impingement causing lower back pain and left leg pain.  PLAN  The patient has tried NSAIDs and physical therapy without relief. The treatment plan includes an epidural steroid injection to reduce inflammation at the site of the herniation. The patient will be referred back to physical therapy to strengthen the affected area. A follow-up appointment will be scheduled in one month to assess the patient's progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Hepatitis C.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Jacqueline is a 60-year-old female who presents to the clinic today following a positive result in a hepatitis C antibody test. She is anxious about the results and denies ever being diagnosed with hepatitis C. The patient admits to intravenous drug use in the past; however, she notes it has been longer than 15 years since her last usage. She also reports a history of heavy alcohol use and currently drinks a beer a day. The patient currently smokes 1 to 2 cigarettes per day.  MEDICAL HISTORY  The patient denies any significant past medical history.  SOCIAL HISTORY  The patient is married with children. She reports history of IV drug use 15 years ago. She currently drinks a beer a day and smokes 1 to 2 cigarettes per day.  FAMILY HISTORY  She reports a family history of hypertension, diabetes, and depression.  MEDICATIONS  Patient denies taking any current medications.  VITALS  All vital signs are within normal limits.  PHYSICAL EXAM  CONSTITUTIONAL: In no apparent distress. CV: Regular rate and rhythm. Grade 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur is appreciated. RESPIRATORY: Lungs are clear without wheezes, rales, or rhonchi. GI/GU: Abdomen is soft with no hepatosplenomegaly. Bowel sounds are present. SKIN: No jaundice.  RESULTS  The HCV antibody test was reviewed today and is positive.  Liver panel revealed an elevated AST at 39 U/L. The ALT, albumin, and total bilirubin were all within normal limits.  ASSESSMENT  Hepatitis C.  PLAN  After reviewing the patient's laboratory findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with her in regard to her current symptoms. Her initial labs were consistent with a hepatitis C diagnosis. I have recommended that we confirm the diagnosis with additional blood work including checking her hepatitis C RNA and HCV genotype. I have also recommended that we obtain an ultrasound elastography to evaluate for fibrosis of the liver.  The patient is married with children and is concerned about their hepatitis C status. I advised the patient that her family should be screened and we will assist her with setting appointments with their primary care physician.  INSTRUCTIONS  The patient will follow up with me in 3 weeks to review her results and discuss further treatment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Headaches.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient reports a history of headaches since her teenage years, which have recently become more frequent and severe.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Constitutional: Denies fever. Eyes: Reports blurred vision on the side of her vision. Ears: Reports ringing in her ears. Neurological: Reports headaches, primarily on the right side and behind the eye, with a pulsing sensation.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Eyes - Funduscopic Exam: Papilledema present. - Extraocular Muscles: Grossly Intact without pain.  Neurological - Cranial Nerves: 1-12 intact, including normal cranial reflexes. - Gait: Normal.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Headaches. - Medical Reasoning: Patient's symptoms are concerning for idiopathic intracranial hypertension, which can cause increased pressure in the brain without a known cause. Symptoms include headaches worsening with activity, ringing in the ears, and changes in vision. - Medical Treatment: Order an MRI to check for any other conditions contributing to symptoms. Perform a spinal tap to evaluate pressure in the brain and potentially relieve some pressure. Refer the patient to a neuro-ophthalmologist for a complete eye exam.  2. Exercise and weight loss. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discuss the importance of exercise and weight loss as part of the treatment plan for idiopathic intracranial hypertension.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Neck pain after a car accident.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Jack is a 69-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for evaluation of neck pain following a car accident one week ago. He reports that his neck and head were jerked forward during the accident, causing pain in the back of his neck. The pain is rated as a 7 out of 10 in severity and worsens with neck movement. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief, which provided minimal relief. He denies any swelling or bruising on his neck.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports neck pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling. Headaches were present initially but have subsided.  VITALS  All vital signs are within the normal limits.  PHYSICAL EXAM  MSK: Examination of the neck: Positive pain to palpation of the soft tissues of the neck. Positive pain with flexion, extension, rotation, and lateral bending of the neck. No pain with palpation of the back or shoulders.  RESULTS  X-rays of the neck were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.  ASSESSMENT  Neck strain, likely due to whiplash from the car accident.  PLAN  After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have prescribed anti-inflammatory medication (Motrin 600 mg every 6-8 hours) and a muscle relaxant (Flexeril 10 mg every 12 hours as needed) for pain management. I have also ordered an MRI of the neck to rule out any nerve impingement or concussion. Once the MRI results are available, I will refer the patient to either physical rehab or a chiropractor for further treatment. The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Right shoulder pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Bobby is a 69-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began a few weeks ago while working on various projects in his backyard. He has had some previous issues with his right shoulder due to a baseball injury when he was younger. The pain is located on the outside of the shoulder and is tender when raising his arm. The pain occurs when moving the arm and is not constant. He has difficulty sleeping due to the pain. He has been taking Advil and icing the shoulder for pain relief.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports right shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.  VITALS  All vital signs are within the normal limits.  PHYSICAL EXAM  MSK: Examination of the right shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.  RESULTS  X-rays of the right shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.  ASSESSMENT  Right shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.  PLAN  After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the right shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his right shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the right shoulder.  INSTRUCTIONS  The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Right elbow pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Mark Jackson is a 45-year-old male with a history of diabetes type 2 and mild intermittent asthma. He presents with right elbow pain for the past three weeks. The patient has been playing tennis more frequently recently. The pain is located on the outside of the elbow and is described as shooting, stabbing, and sharp. The pain is worse with movement and better with rest. The patient has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and ice, but the pain persists.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  Diabetes type 2, mild intermittent asthma, penicillin allergy, and cholecystectomy 10 years ago.  MEDICATIONS  Metformin 500 mg twice a day, Flovent, and Albuterol as needed.  PHYSICAL EXAM  MSK: Moderate lateral epicondylar tenderness of the right elbow. Moderate pain with passive range of motion of the right elbow. Mild pain with resisted extension of the right wrist.  RESULTS  Right elbow X-ray: No acute fracture or other bony abnormality, no malalignment or sign of joint effusion.  ASSESSMENT  1. Acute lateral epicondylitis (tennis elbow) of the right elbow. 2. Diabetes type 2 with slightly elevated blood sugars. 3. Mild intermittent asthma, well-controlled.  PLAN  1. For tennis elbow: Rest the right arm, stop tennis for 4-6 weeks, ice the right elbow 20 minutes 3 times daily, provide a forearm brace, prescribe Ultram 50 mg once per day for pain, and follow up in 4 weeks. 2. For diabetes: Increase Metformin to 1000 mg twice per day, check blood sugar twice daily for 2 weeks, order hemoglobin A1C, CBC, and Chem-12 blood tests. 3. For asthma: Continue Flovent and Albuterol as needed, refill Albuterol prescription.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Kidney stone and management of hypertension and diabetes.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient reports a history of hypertension, diabetes, and multiple kidney stones.  MEDICATIONS  Patient reports taking Norvasc 2.5 mg daily, metformin 500 mg daily, and was prescribed Percocet for kidney stone pain.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or decreased appetite. Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain. Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain. Genitourinary: Denies hematuria or current pain. Musculoskeletal: Denies back pain.  VITALS  Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/90.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Respiratory - Auscultation of Lungs: Clear bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.  Cardiovascular - Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2 out of 6 systolic ejection murmur, unchanged.  Gastrointestinal - Examination of Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation of the abdomen or CVA tenderness.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Kidney stone. - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports a recent kidney stone that has passed. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of hydration and dietary modifications to prevent future kidney stones. - Medical Treatment: Referral to urology for further evaluation and management of recurrent kidney stones.  2. Hypertension. - Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated today but reports normal readings at home. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of home blood pressure monitoring and dietary modifications to limit sodium intake. - Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc 2.5 mg daily. Encourage home blood pressure monitoring and sodium restriction.  3. Diabetes. - Medical Reasoning: Patient's diabetes is currently stable but requires continued monitoring and management. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of diet modification and regular blood glucose monitoring. - Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 500 mg daily. Encourage regular blood glucose monitoring before meals and referral to a dietitian for further dietary guidance.  4. Insomnia. - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports occasional insomnia and difficulty falling asleep. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of proper sleep hygiene and the use of relaxation techniques. - Medical Treatment: Recommend trying 10 mg of melatonin as needed for sleep and continue practicing proper sleep hygiene.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan. Follow-up appointment scheduled for three months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Asthma.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient reports history of asthma, frequent exacerbations, and visits to urgent care and ER. No history of seasonal allergies. No smoking, vaping, or marijuana use.  MEDICATIONS  Patient reports using an albuterol inhaler (Ventolin) almost daily and during exacerbations.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Vitals: Blood pressure 128/82, respiratory rate 16, oxygen saturation 99% on room air. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no rubs, murmurs, or gallops. Lungs: Diminished lung sounds with occasional slight expiratory wheeze bilaterally. Neck: Supple, trachea midline, no lymphadenopathy, no carotid bruit. Hands: Strong bilateral pulses, no clubbing, brisk capillary refill.  Pulmonary function test results consistent with asthma.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Asthma: Moderate intermittent asthma. - Medical Treatment: Start Flovent 110 mcg, 1 puff twice per day. Continue Ventolin inhaler 2 puffs every 4-6 hours PRN. - Patient Education: Importance of consistency with inhaled steroid inhaler to prevent daily symptoms and reduce need for rescue inhaler. - Asthma Action Plan: Develop an asthma action plan to address symptoms and triggers.  Follow up in 30 days or sooner if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Chronic lumbar back pain.  MEDICAL HISTORY  The patient has been experiencing back pain for a couple of years, which started after moving furniture. The pain is described as sharp and stabbing, radiating down the right leg to the big toe. The patient has tried physical therapy and strong pain medications in the past but has not found relief.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports sharp, stabbing pain in the back and right leg. Numbness and tingling in the right leg and foot. No weakness or loss of control of bladder or bowels.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Musculoskeletal: Midline tenderness at L4-L5 disk space with right-sided lumbar paravertebral tenderness. Pain with lumbar flexion. Positive supine straight leg test.  Neurological: Decreased sensation to light touch at the right lateral thigh at L4 dermatome. Patellar and Achilles reflexes are symmetrical.  IMAGING  MRI: Disk herniation with nerve impingement.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Chronic lumbar back pain due to L4-L5 herniated disk with radiculopathy. - Medical Treatment: Spinal injection with corticosteroid under fluoroscopy to reduce inflammation and alleviate pain. - Follow-up: Monitor patient's response to the injection and adjust treatment as needed, with no more than four injections per year.  The patient agrees to proceed with the spinal injection treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Right knee pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  The patient injured their right knee while water skiing about five days ago. They felt something stretch and experienced swelling afterwards. The patient has been taking over-the-counter Aleve and using a cold pack for pain relief.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  Hypertension, managed with Lisinopril 20 mg daily.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Vital Signs: Blood pressure 120/77. Neck: No lymphadenopathy. Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur. Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. Musculoskeletal: Right knee with ecchymosis, edema, and effusion. Pain to palpation of the right medial knee. Decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test, negative Lachman sign. Palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses. No lower extremity edema.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Right knee pain - Suspected medial collateral ligament strain. - Order X-ray of the right knee to rule out fractures. - Refer to physical therapy for strengthening exercises. - Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg once daily for pain and inflammation. - Advise the patient to rest the knee and avoid water skiing until further evaluation.  2. Hypertension - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. - Order lipid panel for monitoring.  3. Health maintenance - Administer tetanus shot as the patient is due for one.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Incidentally found right upper lobe lung nodule.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Patient initially presented to their primary care provider with a cough, which was diagnosed as bronchitis. A chest X-ray was performed to rule out pneumonia, and a lung nodule was discovered. A subsequent CT scan confirmed the presence of the nodule, and the patient was referred to the current provider.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  Rheumatoid arthritis, managed with methotrexate 7.5 mg weekly.  SOCIAL HISTORY  Patient is a former smoker, quit approximately 7 years ago. Enjoys biking and has an active lifestyle.  FAMILY HISTORY  Mother had breast cancer, no history of lung cancer.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath or pain. Musculoskeletal: Reports some swelling in knuckles, consistent with rheumatoid arthritis.  VITALS  Blood pressure: 124/76 mmHg Heart rate: 70 bpm Respiration rate: 16 O2 saturation: 98% on room air No fever.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Respiratory: Lungs clear and equal bilaterally. Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no clicks, rubs, or murmurs. Extremities: Pink, warm, and dry skin. No edema in lower extremities, some swelling in knuckles. Pulses intact and capillary refill brisk.  IMAGING  Chest CT: Solitary 2 cm nodule in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe, smooth in appearance. No evidence of emphysematous disease.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Right upper lobe lung nodule. - Order pulmonary function tests (PFT) for baseline lung function. - Schedule PET-CT to determine if nodule is metabolically active. - Recommend video-assisted thoracoscopy for removal of nodule and small portion of lung, with an expected hospital stay of one night.  2. Rheumatoid arthritis. - Continue following up with rheumatologist and maintain current medication therapy.  Patient agrees with the recommended treatment plan and will proceed with necessary tests and procedures.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Difficulty swallowing.  MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient has a past medical history of diabetes and high blood pressure.  MEDICATIONS  Patient is taking metformin 500 mg twice a day and Norvasc.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Constitutional: No weight loss. Gastrointestinal: Difficulty swallowing solids, no vomiting, no blood in stools.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Neck: No swelling, thyroid feels normal, no masses or lymph nodes. Throat: No masses, swelling, or redness. Lung exam: Clear. Heart exam: Normal, no murmurs. Abdominal exam: Epigastric tenderness, no masses or significant swelling. Extremity exam: Normal. Neurological exam: Normal.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Difficulty swallowing. - Medical Reasoning: Patient has difficulty swallowing solids for the past 4-5 weeks. Physical exam shows no obvious abnormalities in the throat or neck. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of chewing food thoroughly and seeking emergency care if food becomes stuck. - Medical Treatment: Referral to gastroenterology for further evaluation and possible esophageal dilation. Prescription for Prilosec 20 mg once a day to address potential reflux issues.  2. Diabetes. - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking metformin as prescribed and checking blood sugars regularly. Blood sugar levels are within the target range. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of maintaining a healthy lifestyle and monitoring blood sugar levels. - Medical Treatment: Order a hemoglobin A1c test, kidney function test, and referral to ophthalmology for eye examination. Continue metformin and follow up in one month.  3. High blood pressure. - Medical Reasoning: Patient reports taking Norvasc as prescribed and monitoring blood pressure at home. Blood pressure in the office is within normal limits. - Patient Education and Counseling: Discussed the importance of continuing medication and monitoring blood pressure. - Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc and follow up as needed. Refill prescription for Norvasc.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Ankle injury.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Jerry, a 45-year-old male, presents to the clinic with an ankle injury sustained while playing basketball with his son. He reports landing awkwardly after going up for a shot, resulting in a rolled and twisted ankle. The patient is experiencing pain, swelling, and bruising on the outside of the ankle, as well as difficulty walking and a feeling of instability.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Positive for ankle pain, swelling, and bruising. Skin: Intact, no epidermolysis.  VITALS  Not provided.  PHYSICAL EXAM  MSK: Exquisite tenderness laterally and some tenderness over the medial deltoid region. Swelling on the lateral side of the ankle. Brisk capillary refill. No horrible malalignment.  RESULTS  X-ray of the right ankle reveals a displaced lateral malleolus at the Weber C level. No evidence of medial or posterior malleolar fractures.  ASSESSMENT  Lateral malleolar fracture.  PLAN  The patient will require surgery to repair the fracture, which will involve the placement of a plate and screws. He will be prescribed meloxicam to help reduce swelling and advised to ice and elevate the ankle regularly. The patient will be provided with crutches and is expected to be out of action for approximately three months. He is encouraged to continue coaching during this time.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Facial pain.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Mr. Edwards is a 54-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of facial pain. He reports having stabbing, shooting pain in his right cheekbone area for the past 2-3 months. The pain is triggered by certain temperatures and sensory stimuli, such as wind. The episodes of pain can last anywhere from a few minutes to an hour. He has tried ibuprofen, Motrin, and topical treatments without relief. He denies any numbness, tingling, or weakness in the affected area.  MEDICAL HISTORY  No significant medical history reported.  SOCIAL HISTORY  No significant social history reported.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Neurological: Denies numbness, tingling, or weakness in the face.  VITALS  Not reported.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Neurological: Patient follows finger in both directions. Symmetric smile. No weakness in the face. Slightly numb on the right side of the face when tested with cotton. Dull sensation on the right side of the face when tested with a needle.  ASSESSMENT  Trigeminal neuralgia.  PLAN  1. Prescribe Tegretol to help reduce the excitability of the nerve and control pain. 2. Discuss potential side effects of Tegretol, including memory loss, tingling, imbalance, and dermatologic reactions. 3. Consider genetic testing to ensure the safety of Tegretol for the patient. 4. Schedule a follow-up appointment in one month to evaluate the effectiveness of the medication. 5. If pain continues, discuss surgical options to treat the pain.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Right knee pain and instability after a skiing accident.  MEDICAL HISTORY  The patient is generally healthy with no history of high blood pressure or diabetes. She is an active person and a mother of twins.  REVIEW OF SYSTEMS  Musculoskeletal: Reports right knee pain, swelling, and instability.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Cardiovascular: Heart sounds in a regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs. Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation. Musculoskeletal: Edema and effusion over the right knee, pain to palpation of the right lateral knee, decreased flexion and extension, positive Lachman sign, palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulse, no leg edema in the ankle.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Right knee pain and instability. - Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a possible ACL rupture or other ligament damage. - Additional Testing: Order a knee MRI to confirm the diagnosis and assess for any other structural damage. - Medical Treatment: Continue taking ibuprofen for pain relief, and provide a knee brace for support.  2. Follow-up appointment. - Schedule a follow-up appointment after the MRI results are available to discuss treatment options and next steps.  Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT  Neck pain following multiple car accidents.  HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS  Patient has been involved in multiple car accidents, with the most recent one occurring in February. Patient reports sharp, incapacitating neck pain, numbness in left arm and right leg, and muscle spasms. Pain is rated as a 12/10.  PAST MEDICAL HISTORY  Patient has a history of neck pain and has previously been prescribed Fentanyl.  PHYSICAL EXAM  Neck: Pain on palpation of both bony process and muscle. Moderate range of movement. Pain when bending neck forward and backward. No bruising, swelling, or lacerations observed.  IMAGING  X-ray of the neck: No fractures observed.  ASSESSMENT AND PLAN  1. Neck sprain: No fractures observed on X-ray. Will order an MRI to further evaluate the neck and soft tissues. 2. Pain management: Prescribe Robaxin 1500 mg every 6-8 hours to help relax muscles and alleviate pain. Consider local injections and referral to pain medicine if needed. 3. Physical therapy: Refer patient to physical therapy for further evaluation and treatment. 4. Home care: Advise patient to use ice, heat pads, or topical analgesics as needed for pain relief. Provide patient with neck exercises to perform daily.  Patient will follow up after MRI results are available.
